data.title: Japanese to English Pokémon Dictionary
data.meta_description: Hi, I've been working on this for awhile, and it's still a WIP. I hope to get most of the other stuff up soon but I wanted to post this since I'm a bit...
data.text:
Hi, I've been working on this for awhile, and it's still a WIP. I hope to get most of the other stuff up soon but I wanted to post this since I'm a bit tired. For those who will be playing in Japanese but don't understand it, this is a resource for move, nature, item, etc. term translations. Hopefully it can be of help. The terms are based off the 4th gen and I'm going to be adding in 5th gen stuff ASAP.

Japanese to English Pokémon Dictionary

「日本語→英語 ポケモンの辞書」

Index

Post 1:

Note on Japanese Characters

Types

HMs & Moves

Identifying a Move

Post 2:

Natures

Abilities

Items

Locations

Trainer Classes

Post 3:

Useful Terminology Handbook (from PokéDex to Gym Badge)

Note on Japanese Characters

あア

If those characters are displaying as anything other than (that's an image, btw), something is up with your computer/browser's display of Unicode Japanese characters. I'm not tech support so you'll have to look into it yourself, since you can't use this list effectively without Japanese support. Here is a basic page on it, and good luck.

Types

Bug - むし

Dark - あく

Dragon - ドラゴン

Electric - でんき

Fighting - かくとう

Fire - ほのお

Flying - ひこう

Ghost - ゴースト

Grass - くさ

Ground - じめん

Ice - こあり

Normal - ノーマル

Rock - いわ

Poison - どく

Psychic - エスパー

Steel - はかね

Water - みず

Moves

Confirmed Black and White HMs

Cut - いあいぎり

Dive - ダイビング

Fly - そらをとぶ

Strength - かいりき

Surf - なみのり

Waterfall - たきのぼり

So far, this is just a 4th gen list. I'm going to add the known 5th gen moves soon. I think I got all the known 5th gen moves, but please let me know if I missed any! When the games are available, you'll be on your own for the rest until I finish the game and get the time to add them or somebody else edits them in, sorry!

Identifying a Move

There are plenty of circumstances in which you will want to identify a move. To see what's attacking you, to see what you're teaching, to work out which move is which when you select it. If you don't recognise Japanese characters then it can be a little bit difficult, so I wrote this guide to assist you. If you recognise and can type hiragana / katakana, you can use your computer's find function (Ctrl+F, etc.) to quickly scroll through the list.

The first step, when identifying a move, is obviously to check its type where applicable. It’s generally fairly obvious. In the 4th gen, they are identified by little icons like this:

In battle you might not have that available, but try to think using the clues the game gives you. If you have battling animations on then it might give you a bit of a hint as to what type of attack it is. If you are up against an Electric-type like Emonga, then you can probably guess as to what moves it will have, and if it hits your Mijumaru super effectively, it's likely an Electric-type move. You can also use hints like PP, damage, and special/physical type, though those may change in BW.

Here is an example image from Pokémon Diamond.

We know it's Normal and has 35 PP. You probably don't know all of those moves' PP off by heart but you can look in the Normal list and you will probably work out that it is ひっかく, which is Scratch.

​

Locations

シティ -- City

タウン -- Town

もり -- Forest

どうくつ -- Cave

ばんどうろ -- Route

(Cave names are written like -- (name of cave)のどうくつ, like... ハナダのどうくつ is Cerulean Cave, ハナダ being the name of the cave.

Forest names are written the same, ウバメのもり being Ilex Forest. However, White Forest is written differently.

Route names are written like -- (N)ばんどうろ, like... １ばんどうろ is Route 1, 1 being the number of the route.)
